references: Figure 1 show the privacy-utility tradeoff curve under different privacy framework and defense mechanisms. We observe that 1) Our method consistently achieves better accuracy than baseline methods in all cases with same privacy budget. 2) Our method performs better as the budget values becomes smaller (the protection strength becomes more strict). As shown in Table 1, The performance gain increases from a moderate value of 1.36%percent1.361.36\%(ϵ=800italic-ϵ800\epsilon=800) to a significant large value of 8.48%percent8.488.48\%(ϵ=200italic-ϵ200\epsilon=200) on MNIST dataset. 3) Our method is more robust to extremely large distortion. when ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon gets further small to be 606060 (which means more noise are added to model), the distortion noise gets enough large to destroy the training of baseline method, which only have 8.92%percent8.928.92\% accuracy and is worse than random guess. While our method is still available and achieves 51.04%percent51.0451.04\% accuracy. Thus we answered Q1 and Q2.

S6.SS2.SSS0.Px2.tab1.table:
Dataset Metric DP PL
MNIST mse 0.002 -0.078
ssim 0.00% -0.31%
FMNIST mse -0.044 0.015
ssim -0.54% -0.17%
references: First, we formulate privacy-utility trade-off as an optimization problem with regard to the hyperparameter, which aims at finding appropriate hyperparameters that minimizes the utility loss and maintains potential privacy leakage below an acceptable level simultaneously.

We show that the distortion adopted by our algorithm is near-optimal and provide a novel theoretical analysis for the convergence of our proposed algorithm. Specifically, we show that there exists an algorithm satisfying that the utility loss of the algorithm for client k𝑘k at round t𝑡t is close to that of the optimal value subject to the constraints on privacy (Theorem 5.1). As a comparison, [26] formulated the trade-off between privacy and utility as optimization problems beyond the field of federated learning. However, the optimization problems might not be tractable in practice and they only provided a closed-form solution for some special Boolean-valued special cases. Further, we show that the average squared gradient norm of our proposed algorithm is bounded, which is the first convergence result that concerns privacy-utility trade-off with general formulations to our best knowledge (Theorem 5.2).

Given the privacy budget, the optimization problem aims at deriving the value of the hyperparameter for trading-off utility and privacy. Note that for the distribution-independent protection mechanism, the hyperparameter itself depicts the protection mechanism. For distribution-dependent protection mechanisms such as Laplacian mechanism and Gaussian mechanism, the hyperparameter together with the predefined distribution depict the protection mechanism. The optimization problem defined in Eq. (13) is not guaranteed to be convex. It is possibly intractable and has no close-form solutions. We propose an adaptive learning algorithm to solve the optimization problem (Eq. (13)) in Section 5.

Figure 1 show the privacy-utility tradeoff curve under different privacy framework and defense mechanisms. We observe that 1) Our method consistently achieves better accuracy than baseline methods in all cases with same privacy budget. 2) Our method performs better as the budget values becomes smaller (the protection strength becomes more strict). As shown in Table 1, The performance gain increases from a moderate value of 1.36%percent1.361.36\%(ϵ=800italic-ϵ800\epsilon=800) to a significant large value of 8.48%percent8.488.48\%(ϵ=200italic-ϵ200\epsilon=200) on MNIST dataset. 3) Our method is more robust to extremely large distortion. when ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon gets further small to be 606060 (which means more noise are added to model), the distortion noise gets enough large to destroy the training of baseline method, which only have 8.92%percent8.928.92\% accuracy and is worse than random guess. While our method is still available and achieves 51.04%percent51.0451.04\% accuracy. Thus we answered Q1 and Q2.

As Table 2(a) shows, Our method’s empirical protection effect (against DLG) under a certain privacy budget is the same to baseline. That is to say, the theoretical protection extent (claimed by privacy budget) is do supported by the empirical observation (by MSE and SSIM of the reconstructed image). As more Figure in Appendix visualizes, DLG failed to reconstruct images in both methods, and reconstructed images are also very similar in visual. Table 2(b) further reports the empirical utility-privacy tradeoff against DLG attack via the CAP metric. We observe that our method achieves higher CAP value on all datasets and privacy frameworks.

Table 5 shows the detailed quantitive results of privacy-utility trade-off under our privacy framework. Figure 3 shows the client training process under a certain budget value, showing the faster and better convergent curve of our method.

To ensure that protection mechanisms achieve the expected same level protection effects against DLG attack, we further quantitively validate the MSE error and SSIM between DLG-reconstructed images and ground truth. Figure 4 visualize the defense effect at a specific budget and Table 3 and Table 4 report MSE and SSIM results on all budgets. It is observed that, the absolute SSIM under all cases is less than 6% and the mean difference under all budget values is near to zero, indicating the same-level protection effect of our method and baseline.

S6.T2.st1.caption: (a) The average gap of defense effect (measured by MSE and SSIM) between our method and baseline. The differences are near to 0, indicates that the empirical protection effect of two method is quite consistent under the same budget value. Results with more detail is shown in Appendix.
